nodes.id: Incompleteness: The Proof and Paradox of Kurt Gödel
Claude E. Shannon: A Retrospective on His Life, Work, and Impact
Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences Foreign Member 1975
Gödel, Escher, Bach: an Eternal Golden Braid
Basic Research Award Eduard Rhein Foundation 1991
Claude E. Shannon: Founder of Information Theory
Gödel suffered rheumatic fever and lifelong belief in heart damage; frequent ill health episodes
Gödel's philosophical notebooks are being edited at the Kurt Gödel Research Centre at the Berlin-Brandenburg Academy of Sciences and Humanities
According to Adele, Gödel read the Bible in bed every Sunday morning and was religious, though did not go to church
Five volumes of Gödel's collected works have been published
Upon her death in 1981, Adele donated Gödel's papers to the Institute for Advanced Study
Audio Engineering Society Gold Medal Award
Gödel developed an obsessive fear of being poisoned, ate only food prepared by his wife
"Gödel said: 'I like Islam: it is a consistent or consequential idea of religion and open-minded'"
Gödel read Kant; influenced by philosophical idealism and logical realism
Austrian Citizen, then Czechoslovak, then German, then U.S. Citizen
Golden Plate Award of the American Academy of Achievement 1967
Journey to the Edge of Reason: The Life of Kurt Gödel
Gödel died from malnutrition and inanition caused by personality disturbance after refusing to eat
Frank P. Ramsey Professor of Political Economy
Death resulting from refusal to eat due to belief that food was poisoned
Logical Dilemmas: The Life and Work of Kurt Gödel
In the 2023 movie 'Oppenheimer', Gödel is briefly portrayed by James Urbaniak
The Essential Message: Claude Shannon and the Making of Information Theory
Foreign Member of the Royal Society 1968 (ForMemRS)
Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences
Book interweaves the work and ideas of Gödel, Escher, and Bach and discusses implications of incompleteness theorem for computational systems
Gödel stated: 'Religions are for the most part bad, but not religion itself'
Frank Ramsey Professor Emeritus of Economics
In the 1994 film 'I.Q.', Lou Jacobi portrays Gödel
Journey to the Edge of Reason was a New York Times Critics' Top Book of 2021
A Contribution to the Theory of Taxation (1927)
Gödel suffered paranoia, fear of poisoning, spending months in a sanitarium
Kurt Gödel Research Centre, Berlin-Brandenburg Academy of Sciences and Humanities
Frank P. Ramsey Professor of Managerial Economics
Kurt Gödel Research Center for Mathematical Logic
Influential in academic economics; basis for optimal accumulation theory
Gödel read widely on paranormal topics including telepathy, reincarnation, and ghosts
Gödel believed God was personal, remained a theist throughout his life, and called his philosophy rationalistic, idealistic, optimistic, theological
Gödel believed in an afterlife and paranormal topics such as telepathy, reincarnation, and ghosts
The Bit Player is a feature film about Claude Shannon directed by Mark Levinson, premiered at the World Science Festival in 2019.
Gödel described his religion as 'baptized Lutheran (but not member of any religious congregation). My belief is theistic, not pantheistic, following Leibniz rather than Spinoza'
Some scholars suggested Gödel may have had Asperger syndrome or obsessive-compulsive disorder
On April 30, 2016, Google honored Claude Shannon with a Doodle for his 100th birthday.
Gödel formulated a formal proof of God's existence known as Gödel's ontological proof
The Kurt Gödel Society, founded in 1987, is for promoting research in logic, philosophy, and history of mathematics
Awarded annually for outstanding paper in theoretical computer science
Universals of Law and of Fact (1928)
The 'Claude' language model was named in honor of Claude Shannon.
Annual lecture held by the Association for Symbolic Logic since 1990 in honor of Kurt Gödel
